Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: GIGAHERTZ ULTRASONIC FINGERPRINT IMAGERS
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to provide spoof-free biometric fingerprint sensors. Consumer confidence in adopting many technologies such as IoT devices, and reach a cash-less society is limited by our confidence in transactions being fraud-free. Around the world, there are varying degrees of fraud and it is well known that poorer countries have higher levels of fraud then more advanced countries. By providing a trustable biometric device, the proposed commercialization plan will allow lower levels of fraud and allow greater degree of economic activity bringing up standards of living. The technology of GHz ultrasonics for sensing also has the potential for to be used for applications in being able to image baby fingerprints, enable fingerprint readers in fire-arms for authenticated use at very fast speeds, and allow integration with credit and debit cards. The success of the commercial activities will create a new paradigm for trusting the electronic economy.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop revolutionary new biometric sensors. Biometric technologies range from sensing the unique patterns of the eyes, to voice, and fingerprints amongst other markers. Capacitive fingerprint sensors, and optical fingerprint sensors are very commonly found in smartphones and desktop applications. These technologies produce images that are often limited in resolution and are not spoof-proof. For example, optical fingerprint readers can be spoofed by fingerprint images and capacitive fingerprint sensors can be spoofed by skin-like dielectric polymer fingerprint molds. Ultrasonic images offer the potential for detecting tissue material properties that can help identify fake fingerprints. Although many low-frequency technologies for ultrasonic fingerprint sensing are available, very few have made it into the market in large quantities owing to cost, packaging, and insufficient SNR and resolution. In this project the company will extend the frequency of operation to the GHz range to achieve four to eight times the standard industry standard of 500 dpi resolution. Coupled with integrated circuits operating at low voltages, the company aims for integration of the sensors in very thin platforms such as credit cards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The GHz ultrasonic fingerprint sensor is a novel type of fingerprint sensor that aims to solve several important issues in fingerprint sensing. This technology allows for imaging of both mechanical and thermal properties of tissue at a resolution of four to eight times the industry standard 500 dpi, with the ability to transmit through materials such as glass or metal, allowing for virtually spoof-free sensors that can be placed anywhere on a device. Furthermore, the low voltage operation and solidly mounted thin films allow for thin, reliable and low-cost sensors that can enable biometric sensing capabilities in space constrained platforms such as smart cards.

The impact of our technology is that it will allow consumers to trust in and to adopt new technologies such as IoT devices as the threat of fraud will be greatly reduced by our sensors thereby giving consumers confidence that their transactions are fraud-free. Our trustable biometric device will reduce levels of fraud and allow greater degree of economic activity bringing up standards of living. The ability to place these sensors anywhere in a device, even in the lowest cost and smallest devices, will allow manufacturers to easily secure all electronics devices and create devices that consumers can trust.

The goal of this project was to develop a prototype GHz ultrasonic fingerprint sensor and to de-risk various aspects of the technology to demonstrate its technical feasibility and commercial viability. The key outcomes from our Phase 1 work were:

Development of a handheld portable prototype imager: We successfully miniaturized our technology from a benchtop setup that used expensive high frequency electronic test equipment to a handheld printed circuit board (PCB) level prototype that images fingerprints and other surfaces with a 1x64 linear array of transducers. We developed algorithms in Python to plot out and process the fingerprint images. The development of this prototype has significantly accelerated our commercialization efforts as it has allowed us to demonstrate the technology to potential partners and customers.

Development of commercial AlN-on-CMOS monolithic devices:  In collaboration with the SonicMEMS Lab at Cornell, we worked with major foundries to develop AlN-on-CMOS processes for monolithic integration of GHz ultrasonic transducers on CMOS. These efforts have succeeded in demonstrating CMOS drive of monolithically integrated GHz AlN transducers for the first time ever, allowing us to de-risk the technology significantly, giving us confidence on being able to deliver a full-chip monolithically integrated GHz ultrasonic fingerprint sensor.

Development of integrated circuit architecture for 2D sensors: We have developed an architecture that allows us to fit most of the T/R circuitry directly underneath the transducer, within the area of a pixel. Our extracted simulation results indicate that our current pixel architecture is capable of fitting under within a 500dpi resolution sensor pixel, with smaller area consumption possible with CMOS process node scaling. 

Advanced implementations: We have demonstrated the operation of our sensor operation with different packaging that will enable our technology to be widely applicable in systems where existing sensors can be used. These include behind glass, behind metal, and polymer layers. We now understand what it will take in future designs to meet the requirements of biometrics in future electronic systems.

Development of new applications and inventions: Using the prototype board, we were able to demonstrate the potential for using the GHz ultrasonic sensors in AgTech applications as a below-soil sensor. This work vastly increases the impact of our technology to affect future generations by providing new ways to couple technology to agriculture to form internet-of-plants. In addition, we have developed unique energy harvesting devices that can power biometric sensors to enable people to be even safer in making financial transactions.

 


Last Modified: 09/05/2019
Modified by: Justin Kuo
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The GHz ultrasonic fingerprint sensor is a novel type of fingerprint sensor that aims to solve several important issues in fingerprint sensing. This technology allows for imaging of both mechanical and thermal properties of tissue at a resolution of four to eight times the industry standard 500 dpi, with the ability to transmit through materials such as glass or metal, allowing for virtually spoof-free sensors that can be placed anywhere on a device. Furthermore, the low voltage operation and solidly mounted thin films allow for thin, reliable and low-cost sensors that can enable biometric sensing capabilities in space constrained platforms such as smart cards. The impact of our technology is that it will allow consumers to trust in and to adopt new technologies such as IoT devices as the threat of fraud will be greatly reduced by our sensors thereby giving consumers confidence that their transactions are fraud-free. Our trustable biometric device will reduce levels of fraud and allow greater degree of economic activity bringing up standards of living. The ability to place these sensors anywhere in a device, even in the lowest cost and smallest devices, will allow manufacturers to easily secure all electronics devices and create devices that consumers can trust. Our extracted simulation results indicate that our current pixel architecture is capable of fitting under within a 500dpi resolution sensor pixel, with smaller area consumption possible with CMOS process node scaling. Advanced implementations: We have demonstrated the operation of our sensor operation with different packaging that will enable our technology to be widely applicable in systems where existing sensors can be used. These include behind glass, behind metal, and polymer layers. We now understand what it will take in future designs to meet the requirements of biometrics in future electronic systems. Development of new applications and inventions: Using the prototype board, we were able to demonstrate the potential for using the GHz ultrasonic sensors in AgTech applications as a below-soil sensor. This work vastly increases the impact of our technology to affect future generations by providing new ways to couple technology to agriculture to form internet-of-plants.
